media.credit: UGA Finance and Administration Diversity and Inclusive Excellence Committee

text.headline: Steps towards Diversity
text.text:
The Finance & Administration Diversity and Inclusive Excellence Committee is comprised of representatives from across F&A's many units. The committee works to identify and address opportunities for growth within these units and across F&A. In addition to promoting education regarding the three DEI pillars, the committee hosts events promoting community engagement and awareness.

Click here to learn more

text.headline: Holmes-Hunter Academic Building
text.text:
101 Herty Drive, Athens, GA

Hamilton Holmes and Charlayne Hunter-Gault were the first two African American students to enroll at the University of Georgia. They entered the Academic Building on January 9, 1961 to register for undergraduate classes. Later that same year, Mary Frances Early also enrolled as a graduate student at the Academic Building. In 2001, the Academic Building was named for Holmes and Hunter-Gault.


Learn more about this site:

Holmes and Hunter-Gault: They followed their dreams

Holmes-Hunter Academic Building to undergo major renovation

About Hamilton Holmes

About Charlayne Hunter-Gault

View the Holmes-Hunter exhibit

text.headline: UGA Main library
text.text:
320 South Jackson Street

In commemoration of the 60th anniversary of the desegregation of the University of Georgia, the Main Library at UGA is hosting an exhibit that chronicles the historic events of 1961, when Hamilton Holmes and Charlayne Hunter (now Hunter-Gault) became the first African American students admitted to the university.

The exhibit includes images, documents and other items from this significant time period. Designed in collaboration with Hunter-Gault and the Holmes family, the exhibit includes items from the Special Collections Libraries as well as items borrowed from the Holmes family, such as the fraternity sweater that Holmes was wearing in photographs taken when he first received notice of his admission to the university.

The installation begins in the Main Library\u2019s lobby with reproduction items and graphic panels that focus on the events of 1961. The exhibit continues into the first-floor main hallway of the building. Original items in the hallway spotlight the career achievements of Holmes and Hunter-Gault after their graduation from UGA in 1963. Fabric panels in the space explore milestones in the six-decade journey toward a more inclusive and diverse campus.

Learn more about this site:

UGA\u2019s desegregation history on display at Main Library

View the 60th Anniversary of Desegregation exhibit

text.headline: Baldwin Hall Memorial
text.text:
355 S. Jackson Street, Athens, GA

The Baldwin Hall Memorial was dedicated in November 2018 and is located on the south End of the front lawn of Baldwin Hall, near the Old Athens Cemetery. It serves as a place of remembrance for the individuals who were originally buried on this site in the 1800s, most of whom were slaves or former slaves.


Learn more about this site:

Memorial dedicated at Baldwin Hall

UGA unveils memorial to honor slaves\u2019 legacy on campus

View the Baldwin Hall Memorial exhibit

text.headline: The Five - Sanford Stadium
text.text:
100 Sanford Drive, Athens, GA

In the fall of 1971, a decade after the University of Georgia was first desegregated, Richard Appleby, Chuck Kinnebrew, Horace King, Clarence Pope, and Larry West became students at UGA. They would make history as the first African American scholarship football players at UGA. These freshmen students were signed by legendary coach Vince Dooley and would change the face of Bulldog football and Georgia athletics.

Learn more about this site:

The First Five: Georgia Honoring Football Trailblazers

1971: How one year and five men changed the course of Georgia football

The First Five 50th Anniversary Special

View The Five Memorial exhibit

text.headline: Black Fraternities and Sororities Greek Plaza
text.text:
45 East Baxter Street, Athens GA

In the Fall of 2021, campus markers were placed to recognize the nine historically Black fraternities and sororities that are members of the National Pan-Hellenic Council on the West Lawn of the Tate Student Center. In May 1969, the Zeta Pi Chapter of Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity became the first NPHC member organization to establish a charter at the University of Georgia. This was followed shortly thereafter by the Zeta Psi Chapter of Delta Sigma Theta Sorority in November 1969.

The nine-member organizations of the NPHC include: Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity Inc., Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority Inc., Kappa Alpha Psi Fraternity Inc., Omega Psi Phi Fraternity Inc., Delta Sigma Theta Sorority Inc., Phi Beta Sigma Fraternity Inc., Zeta Phi Beta Sorority Inc., Sigma Gamma Rho Sorority Inc., and Iota Phi Theta Fraternity Inc.

Learn more about this site:

UGA to recognize historically Black fraternities, sororities

About the National Pan-Hellenic Council

View the Black Fraternities and Sororities Greek Plaza exhibit

text.headline: Hugh Hodgson School of Music
text.text:
250 River Road, Athens, GA

Richard Graham was the former director of the Hugh Hodgson School of Music in the Franklin College of Arts and Sciences. He came to the university in 1968 as a visiting professor and permanently joined the faculty the following year, becoming the first full-time African American faculty member at the University of Georgia.

Graham was a pioneer in the discipline of music therapy, the application of music to restore, maintain or improve mental and physical health. Once considered a subgenre of music education, Graham was a leading force behind the establishment of music therapy as a separate discipline. He also was responsible for its establishment at UGA, transforming a fledgling program to one of the most respected programs in the country. While at UGA, Graham served as president of the National Association of Music Therapy and as editor of the Journal of Music Therapy. He retired in 2000 after 32 years of service.


Learn more about this site:

Johnson, Graham receive 2022 President\u2019s Medal

A Tribute to Richard M. Graham

text.headline: Mary Frances Early College of Education
text.text:
110 Carlton Street, Athens, GA

On August 16, 1962, Mary Frances Early became the first African American to graduate from the University of Georgia. She obtained a master\u2019s degree in music education and later returned to UGA to earn a Specialist in Education degree. The College of Education was named in Mary Frances Early\u2019s honor in February 2020.

Learn more about this site:

UGA College of Education named for Mary Frances Early

Invisible no more: UGA names college after first Black graduate

Author Talks | Mary Frances Early

About Mary Frances Early

View the Mary Frances Early exhibit

text.headline: Shirley Mathis McBay Science Library
text.text:
210 D.W. Brooks Drive, Athens, GA

In 1966, Dr. Shirley McBay was a trailblazing mathematician and UGA\u2019s first African American Ph.D. graduate. This is notable for many reasons including the fact that the first Ph.D. was not awarded at UGA until 1951, and the university had only desegregated in 1961. The UGA Science Library was renamed in her honor in December 2021.

Dr. McBay also earned master's degrees in math and chemistry from Atlanta University (now Clark Atlanta University). After serving at Spelman College as a math professor, McBay became MIT's dean for student affairs and chair of the National Science Foundation's committee on equal opportunity in science and engineering. McBay was an early champion of the need for diversity in the STEM fields, founding the Quality Education for Minorities Network (QEM), a nonprofit that she led for two decades.


Learn more about this site:

Shirley McBay: The advocate

Regents name two UGA buildings after barrier-breaking Black students

McBay Science Library dedicated for UGA alumna

Georgia Groundbreaker: Dr. Shirley McBay

View the Shirley Mathis McBay Science Library exhibit

text.headline: Black-Diallo-Miller Hall
text.text:
315 Baxter Street, Athens GA

In 1962, Harold A. Black, Mary Blackwell Diallo, and Kerry Rushin Miller became the first Black students to enroll at the University of Georgia as freshmen and complete their undergraduate degrees. Black-Diallo-Miller Residence Hall opened in Fall 2022 and was named in their honor to mark the 60th anniversary of their enrollment.

Black was the University's first African American male freshman and the first African American graduate of the Terry College of Business. He retired as professor emeritus of the University of Tennessee-Knoxville after 24 years of service, as a professor of finance. Through the years, Black served on the faculties of American University, Howard University, the University of North Carolina, and the University of Florida.

Diallo was the first African American student from Athens to enroll in the University of Georgia. She earned both her bachelor's and master's degrees in French literature from UGA and her doctorate from Emory University. She taught at Morehouse College and Florida A&M University (FAMU), from which she retired in 2021.

Miller was the first African American to earn a bachelor's degree from the University of Georgia in mathematics in 1966 and shortly thereafter began an extensive professional career in the telecommunications industry. She retired from BellSouth after 29 years, primarily based in Charlotte, N.C. As a later member of the Charlotte Club of the National Association of Negro Business and Professional Women's Clubs (NANBPWC), Miller developed an education program designed to help at-risk elementary and middle school students raise their self-esteem, strive for excellence, and achieve their personal best.


Learn more about this site:

About Harold A. Black

About Mary Blackwell Diallo

About Kerry Rushin Miller

UGA dedicates Black-Diallo-Miller Hall residence hall

UGA's first black freshmen - all three - recall what it was like

UGA to name new residence hall for Harold A. Black

Notable Black UGA alumni to be honored on campus buildings

About Black-Diallo-Miller Hall

View the Black-Diallo-Miller Hall installation
